Activity.title: Activity
Activity.description: Represents a specific activity logged by the student.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Activity entity.

duration.description: Duration of the activity in minutes.

date.description: Date of the activity in YYYY-MM-DD format.

startTime.description: Start time of the activity in HH:MM format.

Problem.title: Problem
Problem.description: Represents a problem solved by the student.

id.description: Unique identifier for the ProblemSolved entity.

name.description: Name or topic of the problems solved.

notes.description: Short text response to the problem.

date.description: Date of the problem log in YYYY-MM-DD format.

createdAt.description: Timestamp of when the problem was logged.

Todo.title: Todo
Todo.description: Represents a to-do item for a user.

id.description: Unique identifier for the Todo entity.

title.description: The content of the to-do item.

completed.description: Whether the to-do item is completed.

createdAt.description: Timestamp of when the to-do item was created.

dueDate.description: The date the to-do item is due in YYYY-MM-DD format.

firestore.reasoning:
The Firestore data structure is designed to support the StudyTrack Journal application, prioritizing security, scalability, and debuggability by adhering to the principles of Authorization Independence, Clarity of Intent, DBAC (Database-Based Access Control), and QAPs (Rules are not Filters). Authorization Independence is achieved through structural denormalization.  The structure uses path-based ownership for user-owned data to simplify security rules and ensure efficient data retrieval. Every collection is designed to have a homogeneous security posture.

Specifically, each user's activities, problems solved, and todos are stored under their respective user ID, enabling direct and secure access control using Firebase Authentication. No `get()` calls are necessary for security rules.

QAPs are supported because `list` operations can be secured based on the path structure; a user can only `list` Activities, ProblemsSolved, and Todos under their own `/users/{userId}` path. Data segregation ensures that there are no mixed security requirements within a single collection.
